title: 114_hr359
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a pilot program on dog training therapy within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using trained service dogs to help veterans with post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms. The program will last for five years and will be carried out near three to five medical centers of the Department. The pilot program will be conducted near three to five medical centers of the Department. An appropriate non-government entity for the program is certified in training service dogs and must have specific facilities for grooming, training, wheelchair accessibility, classroom space, staff offices, equipment storage, and other training areas. The pilot program includes training dogs with wheelchairs, outdoor exercise, toileting space, and transportation for field trips. The non-government entity must ensure veterans receive training from certified instructors, select dogs from shelters or foster homes, and ensure dogs have proper temperament and health clearances. The pilot program for training service dogs includes teaching essential commands, living arrangements for dogs in training, hands-on training, maximizing therapeutic benefits for veterans, and providing well-trained service dogs to veterans with disabilities. Hiring service dog training instructors is also a key aspect of the program. The pilot program for training service dogs includes giving preference to veterans who have graduated from treatment programs and received certification in service dog training. The program is administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs through the Recreation Therapy Service and includes hiring instructors with experience in social services and teaching service dog training. The pilot program for training service dogs gives preference to veterans with experience in service dog training. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder can volunteer if resources are available. Data collection is required to assess program effectiveness. The program aims to assist veterans by reducing stigma related to mental health conditions, improving emotional regulation, patience, and sense of purpose, reintegrating into the community, and providing opportunities to help fellow veterans. It also helps in building relationship skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and reducing the use of pain medication. The pilot program aims to assist veterans by reducing stigma related to mental health conditions, improving emotional regulation, and decreasing the use of pain medication. Reports to Congress will include the number of participants, services provided, and effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder and physiological markers. The pilot program aims to assist veterans by reducing stigma related to mental health conditions, improving emotional regulation, and decreasing the use of pain medication. Reports to Congress will include the number of participants, services provided, effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, physiological markers, family dynamics, insomnia and pain management, overall well-being, and recommendations for program extension or expansion. The term "service dog training instructor" is defined as an instructor who directly trains veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder and other post-deployment issues in service dog training and handling.
